question: AKA Kentauroi, half man/half horse creature that inhabited the mountains and forests of Thessaly, were said to be primal - existing in tribes and making their homes in caves, hunted wild animals and arming themselves with rocks and tree branches
The three-headed dog of Greek Mythology, it was its job to guard the entrance to Hades - the underworld where spirits of the dead were the only ones allowed to enter

Fire-breathing monster, she has become one of the most famous female monsters described in Greek mythology, an aura of mystery has always surrounded this creature, even today - the name sometimes refers to a genetic puzzle, Greek sailors considered it very bad omen to see her, she usually appeared right before a disaster, considered a lion/goat/snake combination

Most famous centaur, like others - he had the upper body of a man and the lower body of a horse; however, unlike the others, his front legs were human, it also gave him higher status among the centaurs, was often depicted wearing clothes to show his higher status, he had no desire for drinking or lusting after women like the other centaurs, unique parents - son of Cronos the Titan and Philyra the nymph while the other centaurs were said to be born from Ixion and Nephele, his peaceful nature was thanks to the influence of Apollo and Artemis in his younger years

Hercules captured it as his 7th task, the island of Crete was the home of the legendary King Minos who worshiped bulls, Poseidon (God of the Sea) gave King Minos this magical bull that rose from the sea on the condition that it was to be sacrificed in Poseidon’s honor, Minos was so impressed with this bull that he swapped it with an ordinary bull and released the magical bull into his own herd to trick Poseidon
Giant/monstrous wild porcine that ravaged the farms of Psophis, capturing the boar alive was one of the Twelve Labors faced by demigod hero Heracles at the request of King Eurystheus

Hesiod - children of the Mother Earth goddess Gaia, Uranus, and the god of the sky; born from gods but not invincible - both mortals (humans) and immortals (gods) could kill them, only slightly larger than humans but much stronger, unruly hair and bears, long spears, sturdy shields, animal skins, Gigantomachy - their battle against the gods

In Greek mythology, it was first referred to by the poet Homer as a single monster who had risen from the underworld, another Greek poet (Hesiod) would later add two more of them - resulting in the trio of sister known as Stheno (the Mighty), Euryale (the Far Springer), and the most well-known of the three - Medusa (the Queen); from Hesiod - they were described as the daughters of the sea god Phorcys and his wife (Ceto) who was also his sister

Almost always plural, had the form of a bird with a human female face, often agents of punishment they abducted people and tortured them on their way to Hades’ domain, employed by the God as instruments for the punishment of the guilty, they stole food from their victims and would carry evildoers to Erinnyes of the Furies (female goddesses of vengeance and retribution), their name means snatchers and is thus very appropriate for the acts they carried out, known as the hounds of Zeus, dispatched by the God to snatch away people and things from the earth, sudden and mysterious disappearances were often attributed to them

An ancient Greek mythical dog, magical hunting dog that was destined to always catch its prey, there are no stories concerning its parentage,  some suggest that it is the same dog that watched over baby Zeus on Crete

Beautiful maiden with golden hair, vowed celibacy as a priestess of Athena until she fell in love with Poseidon and married him, Athena punished her by turning her into a Gorgon with bloodshot eyes, snake hair, and anyone she looked upon turning to stone
Brilliant Daedalus, strong Theseus, evil King Minos, and Minos' daughter Ariadne all appear in its story, it resides in the labyrinth built by Daedalus on the island of Crete, slain by Theseus
Centaur, involved in the battle with the Lapiths (a Greek tribe), ferryman who helped transport people like Heracles and his wife across the river Euenos

Beautiful pure white stallion with wings, born from the blood of Medusa (a frightful Gorgon) when Perseus decapitated her, twin brother Chrysasor (decapitated human) was born at the same time, son of Poseidon, service to Zeus

Cyclops - only beasts of the first creation not punished by Zeus when he overthrows his father (Cronus), son of Poseidon, kills/eats a few of Odysseus' crew and is then is fooled and blinded by the hero in the Odyssey

Tough serpent, called a dragon by some, child of Gaea (Mother Earth), guardian of Delphi and its sacred shrine and Oracle, eventually defeated by Apollo on his quest for reveenge for his mother, the creature was sent after Apollo's mother due to Hera's jealousy
Famous mythical sacred bird, cross between a peacock and eagle, spirit of the fire, gave off sunlight, born from the ashes
Almost always plural, sang beautifully to lure passerbys to their deaths, appeared as a cross between a woman and a bird, Odysseus encountered them in the Odyssey
